statement.text: Eversion carotid endarterectomy is a technique where the internal carotid artery is transected at its origin and everted to remove plaque, offering advantages of shorter clamp time, no patch requirement, and natural ICA shortening.
statement.formal: Technique: Transect ICA at origin, evert media/adventitia over plaque; Advantages: No patch needed, shorter clamp time, corrects ICA redundancy; Patency: Equivalent to conventional CEA with patch

explanation.intuition: Instead of opening the artery lengthwise like a hotdog bun, eversion technique is like peeling a banana inside-out - the artery is cut off, turned inside-out to remove plaque, then reconnected.
explanation.key_insight: Eversion endarterectomy corrects ICA redundancy while avoiding the need for patch material.
explanation.technical_details: Eversion carotid endarterectomy involves transecting the internal carotid artery at its origin from the bulb. The adventitia and media are then everted (turned inside-out) over the atheromatous core, which is removed in a circumferential fashion. The ICA is then reimplanted to the CCA. This technique offers shorter clamp times, eliminates need for patch angioplasty, and simultaneously corrects ICA kinking or redundancy. Outcomes are equivalent to conventional CEA with patch in experienced hands.
common_misconceptions: Eversion is technically more difficult than conventional CEA - DEBATED, similar learning curve
Eversion cannot be used for long ICA plaques - FALSE, can extend with ICA eversion
Patch is always better than eversion - FALSE, equivalent outcomes in RCTs
Eversion always shortens the ICA too much - FALSE, controlled by reinsertion point

relative: Plaque extending high into ICA (>3-4 cm)
Very short ICA with no redundancy
Need for shunting (more complex with eversion)

exposure.dissection: Expose CCA, ICA, ECA as usual
exposure.control: Vessel loops or clamps on all vessels

transection.location: ICA at its origin, into the bulb
transection.angle: Oblique to include bulb on CCA side

eversion.technique: Grasp adventitia, evert over plaque core
eversion.direction: Evert from origin toward distal ICA

reimplantation.technique: End-to-side or reattach at oblique angle
reimplantation.adjustment: Trim ICA if redundancy needs correction

shunting.consideration: More difficult with eversion - consider conventional if shunt needed

cca_external_eversion.technique: CCA opened longitudinally, plaque everted from CCA

outcomes.restenosis: Possibly lower than conventional without patch
